notes:
1. Definition

Infiltration is the process by which water on the ground surface enters the soil. It is a key component of the hydrologic cycle.

2. Infiltration Capacity and Rate

  • Infiltration Capacity ($f_c$): The maximum rate at which a given soil can absorb water. It is highest when the soil is dry and decreases as the soil becomes saturated.
  • Actual Infiltration Rate ($f$): The rate at which water is actually entering the soil.
    • If rainfall intensity ($i$) is less than the infiltration capacity ($i < f_c$), then the actual infiltration rate is equal to the rainfall intensity ($f = i$). All the rain soaks in.
    • If rainfall intensity is greater than the infiltration capacity ($i > f_c$), then the actual infiltration rate is equal to the infiltration capacity ($f = f_c$). The excess water becomes surface runoff.

3. Factors Affecting Infiltration

The infiltration capacity is influenced by several factors:

  • Soil Type: Coarse-grained soils like sand have high infiltration rates, while fine-grained soils like clay have very low infiltration rates.
  • Soil Moisture Content: Dry soil can absorb water more quickly than wet or saturated soil.
  • Surface Cover: Vegetation and mulch protect the soil surface from the impact of raindrops, which can seal the surface pores. They also slow down runoff, giving water more time to infiltrate.
  • Land Slope: Steeper slopes promote faster runoff, reducing the time available for water to infiltrate.

solvedExamples.question: Which of the following soil types would be expected to have the highest infiltration capacity?
solvedExamples.explanation: Sand has large pore spaces between its grains, which allows water to pass through it easily. Clay particles are very small and tightly packed, resulting in a very low infiltration capacity.

solvedExamples.question: A steady rain is falling at a rate of 1.5 inches/hour. The soil in the area has an infiltration capacity of 2.0 inches/hour. What is the rate of surface runoff?
solvedExamples.explanation: Runoff only occurs when the rainfall intensity is greater than the infiltration capacity. In this case, the rainfall rate (1.5 in/hr) is less than the rate at which the soil can absorb it (2.0 in/hr). Therefore, all the rain infiltrates, and there is no surface runoff.
